episodes.title: Overview of Windows Server 2012 R2
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:08,758
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,758 --> 00:00:12,563
The MCSA or Microsoft Certified
Solutions Associate is one of

3
00:00:12,563 --> 00:00:16,210
the more popular
certifications from Microsoft.

4
00:00:16,210 --> 00:00:19,160
It's designed to be
a mid-tier certification.

5
00:00:20,200 --> 00:00:23,530
Greater knowledge than somebody who's
just getting started in IT, but

6
00:00:23,530 --> 00:00:25,450
not expert lever, level knowledge.

7
00:00:25,450 --> 00:00:28,330
This is somebody who's been working
in the field for several years and

8
00:00:28,330 --> 00:00:33,700
has had exposure to large and enterprise
size deployments of Microsoft Windows.

9
00:00:33,700 --> 00:00:37,860
The MCSA for
Windows Server 2012 is probably the most

10
00:00:37,860 --> 00:00:40,900
commonly sought-after
certification with Microsoft.

11
00:00:40,900 --> 00:00:44,190
These are for technicians who are not
going to be just working with desktops,

12
00:00:44,190 --> 00:00:46,450
but deploying Windows servers.

13
00:00:46,450 --> 00:00:50,130
These might be email servers,
file servers, print servers.

14
00:00:50,130 --> 00:00:52,040
They might be authentication servers.

15
00:00:52,040 --> 00:00:55,210
There's all sorts of different types
of servers you might deploy, and

16
00:00:55,210 --> 00:00:58,640
the MCSA for Windows Server 2012
covers the majority of them.

17
00:00:58,640 --> 00:01:01,780
It shows typical deployment scenarios for
a server.

18
00:01:01,780 --> 00:01:05,290
How to deploy the software successfully,
how to secure the software and

19
00:01:05,290 --> 00:01:09,000
ensure things are working nice and
smooth, and how to troubleshoot and

20
00:01:09,000 --> 00:01:11,680
isolate and correct issues when they
aren't running nice and smooth,

21
00:01:11,680 --> 00:01:14,080
and that makes this really valuable.

22
00:01:14,080 --> 00:01:18,570
If you're working in IT and you're sitting
at a help desk right now, or you're doing

23
00:01:18,570 --> 00:01:22,060
field repairs on computers and you're
looking to move to that next step in your

24
00:01:22,060 --> 00:01:26,560
career, the MCSA for Windows Server
2012 is normally that next step, right.

25
00:01:26,560 --> 00:01:30,090
This is what gets you out of the field and
back at the data center.

26
00:01:30,090 --> 00:01:32,470
Gets you into the server room,
working in equipment there.

27
00:01:32,470 --> 00:01:35,360
Which is usually a little more
exciting than supporting a desktop.

28
00:01:35,360 --> 00:01:37,850
Which can,
can over time become a bit monotonous.

29
00:01:37,850 --> 00:01:39,360
I think we've all been there.

30
00:01:39,360 --> 00:01:41,210
So, let's take a look at
this certification and

31
00:01:41,210 --> 00:01:42,720
get a better idea of what it entails.

32
00:01:42,720 --> 00:01:46,226
All right, the MCSA has been around for
quite a while now.

33
00:01:46,226 --> 00:01:49,227
I don't think it's actually
reached ten years yet but it's,

34
00:01:49,227 --> 00:01:51,090
it's a good seven years at least.

35
00:01:51,090 --> 00:01:54,410
And it's designed to be the,
well that mid-tier certification.

36
00:01:54,410 --> 00:01:56,500
The name has changed a little
bit over the years, but

37
00:01:56,500 --> 00:01:59,560
now it's just the Microsoft
Certified Solutions Associate.

38
00:01:59,560 --> 00:02:02,500
And Microsoft actually has
several different ones.

39
00:02:02,500 --> 00:02:05,570
The one we're about to cover is
the one for Windows Server 2012.

40
00:02:05,570 --> 00:02:10,130
If your position within the company is
one that allows you to work on servers,

41
00:02:10,130 --> 00:02:11,900
that's what this is designed for.

42
00:02:11,900 --> 00:02:15,940
If you're still at the desktop level but
you want to move into the server world,

43
00:02:15,940 --> 00:02:18,390
again, this is the place
that you wanna go.

44
00:02:18,390 --> 00:02:21,600
But, if you're looking to
do desktop support, well,

45
00:02:21,600 --> 00:02:23,840
the server technologies,
they can be helpful.

46
00:02:23,840 --> 00:02:26,230
They help you to understand what's
going on on the server side.

47
00:02:26,230 --> 00:02:28,440
But it's not necessarily
the right place for you to start.

48
00:02:28,440 --> 00:02:32,840
You typically want to go to the MCSA for
Windows 8 or MCSA for Windows 7.

49
00:02:32,840 --> 00:02:35,250
Now, if you're just
getting started in IT so

50
00:02:35,250 --> 00:02:40,250
you've got a resume full of other jobs and
you're looking to launch an IT career.

51
00:02:40,250 --> 00:02:44,460
Well again the MCSA for Windows servers
is not really a great starting point.

52
00:02:44,460 --> 00:02:46,120
In order to set up a server,

53
00:02:46,120 --> 00:02:49,590
there's a lot of foundational
knowledge that you need to have.

54
00:02:49,590 --> 00:02:52,750
So if you're just starting out,
I recommend you jump over to

55
00:02:52,750 --> 00:02:56,440
like the CompTIA A+ and
CompTIA Network Plus certifications.

56
00:02:56,440 --> 00:02:59,940
Those are great starting points for
launching an IT career.

57
00:02:59,940 --> 00:03:02,470
If you're just getting started
in technology altogether you

58
00:03:02,470 --> 00:03:07,440
probably wanna go to either
the CompTIA IT Fundamentals or the MTA,

59
00:03:07,440 --> 00:03:09,570
the Microsoft Technology Associate.

60
00:03:09,570 --> 00:03:13,410
That's designed for people that are just
getting their feet wet in the IT world.

61
00:03:13,410 --> 00:03:15,270
You'll learn about basic
operating systems.

62
00:03:15,270 --> 00:03:18,740
Now, that's foundational knowledge
that you're expected to already

63
00:03:18,740 --> 00:03:21,050
have by the time you get
to the server level.

64
00:03:21,050 --> 00:03:22,400
So if you don't possess it,

65
00:03:22,400 --> 00:03:25,360
there's things that we'll cover in there
that might be a little over your head.

66
00:03:25,360 --> 00:03:26,940
That if you've missed
the foundational knowledge,

67
00:03:26,940 --> 00:03:28,600
you won't be able to build on top of it.

68
00:03:28,600 --> 00:03:31,120
So, definitely check out those
other certifications if you

69
00:03:31,120 --> 00:03:32,560
haven't done those yet.

70
00:03:32,560 --> 00:03:33,770
But, if you're ready for

71
00:03:33,770 --> 00:03:37,650
Windows Server, then the MCSA
2012 is where you want to go.

72
00:03:37,650 --> 00:03:42,620
Now, the MCSA 2012 is actually
built on three different exams,

73
00:03:42,620 --> 00:03:46,080
and each one kind of divides
the topic up a little bit.

74
00:03:46,080 --> 00:03:48,350
So, here we can see the three
different exams, and

75
00:03:48,350 --> 00:03:51,410
we divide it here on ITPROTV
into three separate shows.

76
00:03:51,410 --> 00:03:53,840
There's the 70-410, 411 and 412 shows.

77
00:03:55,830 --> 00:03:58,940
The first one is installing and
configuring Windows Server 2012.

78
00:03:58,940 --> 00:04:01,010
If this is the first time you've used it,

79
00:04:01,010 --> 00:04:03,140
we'll cover how to install
Windows Server 2012.

80
00:04:03,140 --> 00:04:06,920
How to get it in place, and
how to add roles to it so

81
00:04:06,920 --> 00:04:09,670
your server can actually
perform customized functions.

82
00:04:09,670 --> 00:04:11,540
We'll talk about
the Microsoft Active Directory,

83
00:04:11,540 --> 00:04:14,970
which is a critical technology
throughout your server infrastructure.

84
00:04:14,970 --> 00:04:18,840
We'll talk about other security concepts,
and just some of the neat bells and

85
00:04:18,840 --> 00:04:23,020
whistles that are included
in Windows server.

86
00:04:23,020 --> 00:04:25,680
Then, in 411, we go into
Administering Windows Server 2012.

87
00:04:25,680 --> 00:04:30,440
Once you've brought up these services,
now you need to administer them,

88
00:04:30,440 --> 00:04:31,280
you need to run them.

89
00:04:31,280 --> 00:04:35,100
You need to allow it to scale up
to thousands, tens of thousands,

90
00:04:35,100 --> 00:04:36,680
hundreds of thousands of users.

91
00:04:36,680 --> 00:04:41,000
You need to keep it operational and you
need to do some advanced functionality.

92
00:04:41,000 --> 00:04:44,540
And what, that's what we cover in the
Administering Windows Server 2012 show.

93
00:04:45,780 --> 00:04:48,830
And then the end of it is the 70-412

94
00:04:48,830 --> 00:04:52,930
which is Configuring Advanced
Windows Server 2012 Services.

95
00:04:52,930 --> 00:04:56,890
We actually revisit some of the services
from the first two shows, and

96
00:04:56,890 --> 00:05:00,310
go more in depth,
showing some advanced configurations, and

97
00:05:00,310 --> 00:05:04,550
then we phase in some new technologies
like Active Directory Federated Services

98
00:05:04,550 --> 00:05:08,040
that are extremely complex and
challenging.

99
00:05:08,040 --> 00:05:10,780
Not useful at all for
small and medium businesses.

100
00:05:10,780 --> 00:05:13,990
But for large and
enterprise businesses can revolutionize

101
00:05:13,990 --> 00:05:15,630
the way that you offer
services on the web.

102
00:05:15,630 --> 00:05:19,740
So, definitely stuff that you want
to be aware of, and get exposed to.

103
00:05:19,740 --> 00:05:25,580
Now these exams are designed to be taken
in order, so you should start with 70 410.

104
00:05:25,580 --> 00:05:28,420
And then go on to 411 and
then wrap it up with 412.

105
00:05:28,420 --> 00:05:31,170
If you take them out of order,

106
00:05:31,170 --> 00:05:35,270
each exam assumes you already have
the knowledge from the prior exams.

107
00:05:35,270 --> 00:05:37,490
So for example if you start out on 412,

108
00:05:37,490 --> 00:05:40,680
it assumes you already
have a passing knowledge.

109
00:05:40,680 --> 00:05:43,720
Like you passed the exam,
not just in passing.

110
00:05:43,720 --> 00:05:46,540
Of 410 and 411.
If you don't do that, you'll,

111
00:05:46,540 --> 00:05:49,340
you'll get over your head pretty quick and
then you get frustrated and

112
00:05:49,340 --> 00:05:51,470
it's hard to be successful
when you're frustrated.

113
00:05:51,470 --> 00:05:54,470
So you do wanna pursue those in order.

114
00:05:54,470 --> 00:05:59,220
Now for me, I always recommend that
people go ahead and do all three.

115
00:05:59,220 --> 00:06:01,310
Just watch all three in order.

116
00:06:01,310 --> 00:06:04,030
Even before taking that 410 exam.

117
00:06:04,030 --> 00:06:08,890
And the reason I say that is, each one
builds on the one from before it so

118
00:06:08,890 --> 00:06:10,200
there's some overlap.

119
00:06:10,200 --> 00:06:13,560
And that means you're seeing the same
technologies multiple times and

120
00:06:13,560 --> 00:06:15,030
you learn more about it.

121
00:06:15,030 --> 00:06:18,860
If you were to watch all three of
these shows, 410, 411, and 412,

122
00:06:18,860 --> 00:06:23,690
you'll be much more likely to pass that
410 exam the first time you go in there

123
00:06:23,690 --> 00:06:25,990
cuz you've seen the technology so
many times.

124
00:06:25,990 --> 00:06:26,620
All right?

125
00:06:26,620 --> 00:06:29,120
So how you choose to watch
them is ultimately up to you,

126
00:06:29,120 --> 00:06:32,360
but at a minimum,
you do want to watch them in order.

127
00:06:32,360 --> 00:06:35,550
Start with 410, and
then move through each.

128
00:06:35,550 --> 00:06:38,800
When you're ready to take the exam,
the exams are administered through

129
00:06:38,800 --> 00:06:42,540
Pearson VUE, so
you'll just jump over to their website.

130
00:06:42,540 --> 00:06:45,930
You can go straight to it at
www.pearsonvue.com/Microsoft.

131
00:06:45,930 --> 00:06:48,770
That'll take you to Microsoft's page.

132
00:06:48,770 --> 00:06:53,957
And remember VUE is spelled V U E and
so it's pearsonvue.com/microsoft.

133
00:06:53,957 --> 00:06:59,200
The exams are $150 a piece and
you gotta take three of them so

134
00:06:59,200 --> 00:07:02,510
unfortunately there is a little bit
of a shock to the wallet on this one.

135
00:07:02,510 --> 00:07:07,500
Assuming you pass on the first time it'll
be about $450 to take the three exams.

136
00:07:07,500 --> 00:07:11,420
Once you pass,
you get your MCSA Window's Server 2012.

137
00:07:11,420 --> 00:07:17,830
Now the MCSA Windows Server 2012 is also
the first step in obtaining the MCSE.

138
00:07:17,830 --> 00:07:21,120
So once you've completed this
certification the next step is that

139
00:07:21,120 --> 00:07:22,840
MCSE that you hear a lot
of people talk about.

140
00:07:22,840 --> 00:07:26,310
Right, that's the, the certification
Microsoft has that's the most famous.

141
00:07:26,310 --> 00:07:28,720
Everybody's heard of the MCSE.

142
00:07:28,720 --> 00:07:30,500
And that's a lot of people's goal.

143
00:07:30,500 --> 00:07:34,490
But, the MCSE is not designed for
somebody getting started.

144
00:07:34,490 --> 00:07:38,140
It's for somebody who's already
got a wealth of experience.

145
00:07:38,140 --> 00:07:40,430
Already has their MCSA, and

146
00:07:40,430 --> 00:07:45,450
is moving into that larger
consultant type design environment.

147
00:07:45,450 --> 00:07:49,380
And that's a lot different than the person
who's doing the day to day work.

148
00:07:49,380 --> 00:07:51,710
The MCSA is for the doer.

149
00:07:51,710 --> 00:07:52,810
The person who's in the field.

150
00:07:52,810 --> 00:07:54,600
The grunt who's actually
making things happen.

151
00:07:54,600 --> 00:07:56,750
Right?
You're the one bringing up servers and

152
00:07:56,750 --> 00:07:57,310
troubleshooting.

153
00:07:57,310 --> 00:07:58,160
Replacing hard drives.

154
00:07:58,160 --> 00:08:00,260
You're the one who's
actually making things work.

155
00:08:00,260 --> 00:08:04,220
So in a lot of ways, the knowledge we
cover in the MCSA certification is more

156
00:08:04,220 --> 00:08:09,140
valuable than what we learn in the MCSE
and the MCSA is a lot more entertaining in

157
00:08:09,140 --> 00:08:12,770
my opinion because you know, you get
to use a lot of these technologies.

158
00:08:12,770 --> 00:08:14,280
So keep that in mind as you go through and

159
00:08:14,280 --> 00:08:18,570
study that the MCSA is a great place to
start if you're already somebody who has

160
00:08:18,570 --> 00:08:22,110
that experience and you're looking to get
that documented, get it on your resume and

161
00:08:22,110 --> 00:08:26,200
learn all the different things
that Windows Server 2012 can do.

162
00:08:26,200 --> 00:08:29,070
All right, well, if that's what you're
looking for, you're in the right place.

163
00:08:29,070 --> 00:08:31,200
Stay tuned, our episodes are coming up.

164
00:08:31,200 --> 00:08:34,510
If not, keep in mind all the other
certifications that I mentioned.

165
00:08:34,510 --> 00:08:36,590
There's an appropriate one for
you in there somewhere.

166
00:08:36,590 --> 00:08:39,720
You just gotta look to find it and
then pursue your goal.

167
00:08:39,720 --> 00:08:42,890
Regardless of which route you go,
I wish you the best of luck on your exam.

168
00:08:42,890 --> 00:08:44,320
And for those of you sticking with me,

169
00:08:44,320 --> 00:08:46,272
I'll see you in the episodes
here in just a moment.

170
00:08:46,272 --> 00:08:53,079
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode Mike and Don continue their discussion on high availability. They dive into the world of failover clustering. They install and configure failover clustering and create a highly available file server. They also discuss the different quorum options that are available in 2012 R2 as well as Cluster-Aware Updating.

7

9

10

>> We've got a fun episode ahead of us.

11

12
00:00:49,570 --> 00:00:53,860
>> Absolutely, we started high
availability talking about network

13
00:00:53,860 --> 00:00:58,550
load balancing, which was cool, but
there were some little shortcomings to it.

14
00:00:58,550 --> 00:01:00,180
>> Yeah.
>> Like the fact that it didnt synchronise

00:01:00,180 --> 00:01:02,590
data between nodes and-
>> Right.

16
00:01:02,590 --> 00:01:04,805
>> But easy, cheap, fast to get it set up.

17
00:01:04,805 --> 00:01:06,200
>> Mm-hm.
>> And it does what we need it to do for

18
00:01:06,200 --> 00:01:07,110
certain situations.

19
00:01:07,110 --> 00:01:08,520
>> But
today we're gonna break out the big guns.

20
00:01:08,520 --> 00:01:09,310
>> Yeah, we are.
>> Right?

21
00:01:09,310 --> 00:01:13,210
We're gonna take a look at what's called
failover clustering, and failover

22
00:01:13,210 --> 00:01:17,655
clustering is a function of Windows that's
designed to have more than one server, and

23
00:01:17,655 --> 00:01:21,435
if a server fails,
all of your functions, your services,

24
00:01:21,435 --> 00:01:24,825
whatever, can jump over to
another set of hardware, and

25
00:01:24,825 --> 00:01:29,775
hopefully do it live while people are in
the system and have them not even notice.

26
00:01:29,775 --> 00:01:30,975
>> That's the impressive part.

27
00:01:30,975 --> 00:01:34,025
Lose a ping or two and just,
they don't even know what's going on.

28
00:01:34,025 --> 00:01:35,475
>> Yeah, and
usually it's just like that, right?

29
00:01:35,475 --> 00:01:38,110
Just maybe one or
two pings A couple of seconds.

30
00:01:38,110 --> 00:01:38,890
>> Yup.

31
00:01:38,890 --> 00:01:39,900
>> So very, very fast.

32
00:01:39,900 --> 00:01:40,725
Very, very cool.

33
00:01:40,725 --> 00:01:41,670
>> Mm-hm.

34
00:01:41,670 --> 00:01:43,460
>> Little bit on
the expensive side though.

35
00:01:43,460 --> 00:01:46,270
>> Yeah.
>> Because to do true failover clustering,

36
00:01:46,270 --> 00:01:47,495
there's some hardware requirements.

37
00:01:47,495 --> 00:01:48,520
>> Mm-hm
>> We have to meet,

38
00:01:48,520 --> 00:01:49,715
it's specific requirements, too.

39
00:01:49,715 --> 00:01:50,890
>> Mm-hm.

40
00:01:50,890 --> 00:01:52,860
So before we jump in to configuring it,

41
00:01:52,860 --> 00:01:56,000
I do want to take a look at
Microsoft's configuration page.

42
00:01:56,000 --> 00:01:57,465
They have it on the, the tech nav site.

43
00:01:57,465 --> 00:01:58,210
>> Mm-hm.

44
00:01:58,210 --> 00:02:01,630
>> Because there, there's a few little
caveats I want to point out, alright.

45
00:02:01,630 --> 00:02:05,220
I guess before we jump too far, you know,
what, what is clustering, right.

46
00:02:05,220 --> 00:02:06,950
>> Yeah, you have one of
those pretty diagrams for us?

47
00:02:06,950 --> 00:02:08,090
>> Yeah, well, you know what I'm gonna do,

48
00:02:08,090 --> 00:02:11,320
I'm gonna take the,
>> The one that we did for network

49
00:02:11,320 --> 00:02:14,210
load balancing, and I'm just gonna modify
it a bit to kinda show our clusterings.

50
00:02:14,210 --> 00:02:16,490
So let's, oh, I probably need
to share my screen, though.

51
00:02:16,490 --> 00:02:18,540
We're not gonna get too far without that,
will we?

52
00:02:18,540 --> 00:02:19,715
>> I can see it if I peek over here.

53
00:02:19,715 --> 00:02:21,310
>> [LAUGH]
>> It looks really nice guys.

54
00:02:21,310 --> 00:02:24,980
>> Well, as long as you can see it,
Mike, yeah then everybody else.

55
00:02:24,980 --> 00:02:26,250
There we go.

56
00:02:26,250 --> 00:02:31,380
>> All right, so
this is going to be fail over clustering.

57
00:02:31,380 --> 00:02:34,100
All right, so in our last episode
we talked about network load

58
00:02:34,100 --> 00:02:34,730
balancing
>> Mm-hm.

59
00:02:34,730 --> 00:02:38,770
>> And we talked about how we have a
virtual IP that's shared between machines

60
00:02:38,770 --> 00:02:40,590
and, and traffic is balanced across them.

61
00:02:40,590 --> 00:02:43,100
>> Right.
>> All right, well

62
00:02:43,100 --> 00:02:45,200
the nice thing about this
was users could connect,

63
00:02:45,200 --> 00:02:48,925
they could connect to anybody in that
>> In that node, or cluster.

64
00:02:48,925 --> 00:02:49,440
>> Hm-hm.

65
00:02:49,440 --> 00:02:51,490
>> So there, it,
it could be up to 32 nodes.

66
00:02:51,490 --> 00:02:53,860
>> Right.
>> All of them were active

67
00:02:53,860 --> 00:02:56,320
in servicing there.

68
00:02:56,320 --> 00:02:56,980
>> Right.

69
00:02:56,980 --> 00:02:59,460
>> But,
if a user was connected to one server and

70
00:02:59,460 --> 00:03:01,275
they were in the middle
of doing something.

71
00:03:01,275 --> 00:03:01,820
>> Hm-hm.

72
00:03:01,820 --> 00:03:05,880
>> And that server failed, they would
get shifted over to a new server.

73
00:03:05,880 --> 00:03:08,010
>> Well, whatever is in ram would be lost.

74
00:03:09,020 --> 00:03:10,160
Windows load balancing or

75
00:03:10,160 --> 00:03:13,620
network load balancing does not
synchronize memory between the nodes.

76
00:03:13,620 --> 00:03:16,460
It doesn't even synchronize the files,
it's up to us to do that.

77
00:03:16,460 --> 00:03:20,890
So, it gives us basic load balancing but
not a lot of functionality.

78
00:03:21,920 --> 00:03:24,160
>> If we do clustering on the other hand.

79
00:03:24,160 --> 00:03:24,760
>> Right.

80
00:03:24,760 --> 00:03:27,710
>> Clustering synchronizes
all sorts of things.

81
00:03:27,710 --> 00:03:29,370
>> Yeah,
cuz you're really using shared storage.

82
00:03:29,370 --> 00:03:31,510
So, when you write from, it doesn't
matter which node you're writing from,

83
00:03:31,510 --> 00:03:32,660
you're writing to the same location.

84
00:03:32,660 --> 00:03:35,455
>> Yeah, so no more having to
synchronize data between nodes.

85
00:03:35,455 --> 00:03:36,000
>> Mm-hm.

86
00:03:36,000 --> 00:03:39,380
And if a user is half way through
something on one server, and

87
00:03:39,380 --> 00:03:42,830
a fail over happens, well, now their
half way through it on the other server.

88
00:03:42,830 --> 00:03:44,120
It resumes the session and

89
00:03:44,120 --> 00:03:47,680
it's designed to be completely
invisible to the end user.

90
00:03:48,750 --> 00:03:52,220
Network load balancing,
it's invisible to most users, right.

91
00:03:52,220 --> 00:03:53,695
Clustering is invisible to all of them.

92
00:03:53,695 --> 00:03:55,000
[INAUDIBLE]
>> I guess the only thing we don't

93
00:03:55,000 --> 00:03:56,450
get with the cluster,
we don't get the scalability,

94
00:03:56,450 --> 00:03:59,900
because you still just have the one
node actually performing the job.

95
00:03:59,900 --> 00:04:04,330
So you get that high availability but not
the scalability, whereas NOB gives us both

96
00:04:04,330 --> 00:04:07,880
scalability and availability,
and it's a big trade off, right?

97
00:04:07,880 --> 00:04:13,080
In a cluster, even with multiple nodes,
you really have one node that's active.

98
00:04:13,080 --> 00:04:15,970
And I'll talk a little bit
later about how to kind of work

99
00:04:15,970 --> 00:04:18,160
around that to get more
functionality out of it.

100
00:04:18,160 --> 00:04:22,251
But just at the basics,
if you have a two node cluster,

101
00:04:22,251 --> 00:04:26,620
one node is doing work, the other node
is sitting there waiting For failure.

102
00:04:26,620 --> 00:04:27,140
>> Right.

103
00:04:27,140 --> 00:04:30,660
>> That way when failure does happen,
it can jump right in and get to work.

104
00:04:30,660 --> 00:04:33,310
Now, we could have up to
eight nodes in a cluster.

105
00:04:33,310 --> 00:04:34,170
Did they bump that up?

106
00:04:34,170 --> 00:04:36,250
>> Gosh, I hope, I say, 64?

107
00:04:36,250 --> 00:04:37,360
>> Okay, then they've gone up.

108
00:04:37,360 --> 00:04:38,750
>> Yeah,
they have definitely changed that.

109
00:04:38,750 --> 00:04:42,010
>> So we, we can have quite a few
nodes inside of the cluster.

110
00:04:42,010 --> 00:04:44,245
If only one's active,
why do we need all those other nodes?

111
00:04:44,245 --> 00:04:46,340
>> Hm-hm.
>> Well, we can make different nodes

112
00:04:46,340 --> 00:04:47,190
>> Active for

113
00:04:47,190 --> 00:04:48,850
different elements of the cluster.

114
00:04:48,850 --> 00:04:50,640
>> Right.
>> So we can get them doing more

115
00:04:50,640 --> 00:04:51,220
than one thing.

116
00:04:51,220 --> 00:04:54,260
Mike's looking up the maximum
number of those right now.

117
00:04:54,260 --> 00:04:59,450
So, the way that clustering works is we
have two servers just like before and

118
00:04:59,450 --> 00:05:05,200
we have a shared IP just like before,
the difference being the shared IP

119
00:05:05,200 --> 00:05:09,060
will only be attached to one host.

120
00:05:09,060 --> 00:05:11,840
It won't actually be
attached to two of them.

121
00:05:11,840 --> 00:05:16,410
It's just attached to one, and that's
the one that's answering to that IP.

122
00:05:16,410 --> 00:05:20,820
The other server is aware of that IP, so

123
00:05:20,820 --> 00:05:25,440
server two would know that that IP existed
But it's not going to answer to it.

124
00:05:25,440 --> 00:05:28,710
Just the active node answers to it.

125
00:05:28,710 --> 00:05:30,420
And if there's a failure,

126
00:05:30,420 --> 00:05:32,470
then server two will take over that IP
>> Mm-hm

127
00:05:32,470 --> 00:05:34,430
>> And start to respond to it.

128
00:05:34,430 --> 00:05:38,295
On the back end Let me move
all this down a bit here.

129
00:05:38,295 --> 00:05:39,235
>> Yeah.

130
00:05:39,235 --> 00:05:43,715
>> On the back end, we have shared
storage, and that shared storage normally

131
00:05:43,715 --> 00:05:47,280
takes the form of like a SAN,
a storage area network.

132
00:05:47,280 --> 00:05:47,875
>> Mm-hm.

133
00:05:47,875 --> 00:05:50,250
>> And that SAN
>> That's sitting back there.

134
00:05:50,250 --> 00:05:54,100
You know it might be piles of disks,
right?

135
00:05:54,100 --> 00:05:56,230
You just never known with a SAN.

136
00:05:56,230 --> 00:05:59,590
So, this is all running inside of
some kind of storage network and

137
00:05:59,590 --> 00:06:04,670
it's sitting back there all happy and
go lucky and the servers connect to it.

138
00:06:04,670 --> 00:06:07,930
Well, both servers are going
to connect to that SAN, so

139
00:06:07,930 --> 00:06:12,240
we're gonna have a connection
Connection from, we'll go orange.

140
00:06:12,240 --> 00:06:16,239
So we're gonna have a connection
from this server to there, and

141
00:06:16,239 --> 00:06:19,510
we'll have a connection
from this server to there.

142
00:06:19,510 --> 00:06:22,090
They're both connected to
the same set of storage.

143
00:06:22,090 --> 00:06:23,895
That's the shared storage
Mike was talking about.

144
00:06:23,895 --> 00:06:24,700
>> Mm-hm.

145
00:06:24,700 --> 00:06:28,490
>> So if I have a resource
like a file server, right?

146
00:06:28,490 --> 00:06:30,850
And I've got files stored on the SAN, and

147
00:06:30,850 --> 00:06:33,570
this server is serving them
up to all of our clients.

148
00:06:33,570 --> 00:06:34,760
Our clients connect to one IP.

149
00:06:34,760 --> 00:06:35,340
>> Right.

150
00:06:35,340 --> 00:06:37,370
>> The IP is connected to this server.

151
00:06:37,370 --> 00:06:39,560
This server can access the SAN.

152
00:06:39,560 --> 00:06:45,084
If a failure happens or
if I initiate fail over, the IP will

153
00:06:45,084 --> 00:06:49,460
move to this other server,
if I can click on it, there we go.

154
00:06:50,610 --> 00:06:54,630
It will move over to the other server,
the clients will connect to it, and

155
00:06:54,630 --> 00:06:56,990
that server is now connected
to the SAN and has access.

156
00:06:56,990 --> 00:07:00,470
Just the same resources so it's.

157
00:07:00,470 --> 00:07:04,520
If this server just had a failure that
was something simple like one drive going

158
00:07:04,520 --> 00:07:07,320
bad or something then memory
would synchronize over and

159
00:07:07,320 --> 00:07:09,690
there'd be absolutely no loss of session.

160
00:07:09,690 --> 00:07:13,940
If this computer completely powered off
though, pretty hard to get the ram out of

161
00:07:13,940 --> 00:07:17,530
a machine that's off and so then you do
lose session, so that does happen, and

162
00:07:17,530 --> 00:07:19,698
to rewind it is,
it went from 16 in 2008 to 64 in 2012.

163
00:07:19,698 --> 00:07:23,977
[CROSSTALK] increased the number
of virtual machines you can run,

164
00:07:23,977 --> 00:07:27,643
from 1,00 0 in 2008 to what was it 8,000.

165
00:07:27,643 --> 00:07:28,215
>> Well, that might be enough.

166
00:07:28,215 --> 00:07:29,722
>> Yeah, it should be.

167
00:07:29,722 --> 00:07:31,530
>> [LAUGH]
>> 1,024 per knot.

168
00:07:31,530 --> 00:07:34,800
>> Yeah.
>> Up to 8,000 max.

169
00:07:34,800 --> 00:07:39,250
>> Now, I've taught Microsoft classes for
years and so has Mike, and in the old days

170
00:07:39,250 --> 00:07:42,750
when we taught this, we usually taught
it talking about file services.

171
00:07:42,750 --> 00:07:45,540
Setting up a file server
with a cluster and stuff.

172
00:07:45,540 --> 00:07:48,133
Thanks to services like DFS,
that distribute to file system.

173
00:07:48,133 --> 00:07:50,376
You don't really need clustering for that.

174
00:07:50,376 --> 00:07:53,503
>> A lot less expensive, easier to
configure- Same thing with, like,

175
00:07:53,503 --> 00:07:54,567
web servers and stuff.

176
00:07:54,567 --> 00:07:56,861
You don't necessarily need clustering for
them any more either.

177
00:07:56,861 --> 00:08:01,426
So the number one use we see for
clusters like these today

178
00:08:01,426 --> 00:08:06,260
are SQL database servers and
virtual machine hosts.

179
00:08:06,260 --> 00:08:11,100
And when you do Hyper-V on a clustered
environment, it's awesome.

180
00:08:11,100 --> 00:08:11,843
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, it is.

181
00:08:11,843 --> 00:08:14,834
>> You can have a virtual machine
running on this host right here,

182
00:08:14,834 --> 00:08:17,656
you could fail the virtual
machine over to this other host,

183
00:08:17,656 --> 00:08:20,120
moving it to a complete
different set of hardware.

184
00:08:20,120 --> 00:08:21,380
>> Mm-hm.

185
00:08:21,380 --> 00:08:22,650
>> And the end users don't even notice.

186
00:08:22,650 --> 00:08:25,224
You know, they lose one or
two pings, the transition happens,

187
00:08:25,224 --> 00:08:27,955
and the virtual machine is now live
on this other piece of hardware.

188
00:08:27,955 --> 00:08:28,935
>> That is impressive stuff.

189
00:08:28,935 --> 00:08:30,027
>> It's really cool.

190
00:08:30,027 --> 00:08:33,600
So that's what we're going to show you
in this episode is, we're going to set

191
00:08:33,600 --> 00:08:37,300
up clustering between two servers and
then we're going to add on Hyper-V to it.

192
00:08:37,300 --> 00:08:38,665
And we'll create a virtual machine and

193
00:08:38,665 --> 00:08:41,281
we'll show failing that virtual machine
over from hardware to hardware.

194
00:08:41,281 --> 00:08:41,983
>> Nice.

195
00:08:41,983 --> 00:08:45,120
>> I've done this in a number of
environments, and I've done it with

196
00:08:45,120 --> 00:08:49,510
Hyper-V as well as VMWare and Sun Server,
they all kind of support the same stuff.

197
00:08:49,510 --> 00:08:50,580
It's really neat.

198
00:08:50,580 --> 00:08:52,518
It does create a little challenge, though.

199
00:08:52,518 --> 00:08:57,469
I used to work in a data center where we
had about 200 servers, physical servers.

200
00:08:57,469 --> 00:09:01,503
And you'd come in in the morning, and when
you were looking for a virtual machine,

201
00:09:01,503 --> 00:09:05,262
you never really knew what physical
hardware it was gonna be on that morning.

202
00:09:05,262 --> 00:09:06,319
You'd come in and-
>> Right, who's hosting that day?

203
00:09:06,319 --> 00:09:08,230
>> Yeah,
it could be on any of the hosts, and

204
00:09:08,230 --> 00:09:10,755
it's because it's not tied
to the hardware anymore.

205
00:09:10,755 --> 00:09:13,940
You can bounce around thanks
to the cluster services.

206
00:09:13,940 --> 00:09:18,650
And that's a great way to get all of

episodes.description: In this episode Mike and Don take a look at configuring failover clustering roles. They demonstrate how to configure role-specific cluster settings as well as continuously available shares to maintaining availability in the event of failure. episodes.description: In this episode Mike and Don take a look at configuring Dynamic Access Controls through the Active Directory Administrative Center. episodes.description: In this episode Mike and Don take a look at business continuity and disaster recovery and the various tools available to implement them. They demonstrate Windows Server backups and performing a Bare Metal Restore (BMR) as well as introducing Microsoft Azure backups. They also discuss Hyper-V Replica and its failover settings.

This storage here needs to be identical,
or as near identical as possible,

1732
01:20:36,358 --> 01:20:38,535
over here in the other location.

1733
01:20:38,535 --> 01:20:46,104
Now, if we have a SAN like this, most
storage area network vendors like EMC and

1734
01:20:46,104 --> 01:20:51,037
HP, those guys,
they have replication suites and

1735
01:20:51,037 --> 01:20:55,020
technologies built into their SAN.

1736
01:20:55,020 --> 01:20:59,110
And I'll tell you guys,
it's almost always an extra license.

1737
01:20:59,110 --> 01:21:01,840
So you just dropped $40,000 on a SAN.

1738
01:21:01,840 --> 01:21:05,490
Be ready for another 12,000 for
that replica license or

1739
01:21:05,490 --> 01:21:07,630
whatever it is that they charge.

1740
01:21:07,630 --> 01:21:12,630
In fact, the only high end SAN vendor
that I know of that ever included it was

1741
01:21:12,630 --> 01:21:14,850
EqualLogic, which is now Dell.

1742
01:21:14,850 --> 01:21:18,970
So they used to always include it,
but EMC and the other guys,

1743
01:21:18,970 --> 01:21:21,620
they always charged a little extra for
that license.

1744
01:21:21,620 --> 01:21:26,490
And what it does is it lets you
set up replication between your

1745
01:21:26,490 --> 01:21:31,760
two SANs so that as you write data to one,

1746
01:21:31,760 --> 01:21:35,520
it's automatically sending a copy
of that data to the other one.

1747
01:21:35,520 --> 01:21:38,150
Data is being replicated back and forth.

1748
01:21:38,150 --> 01:21:42,870
So our nodes, our cluster,
doesn't to know anything about that.

1749
01:21:42,870 --> 01:21:46,180
It's completely independent of Windows.

1750
01:21:46,180 --> 01:21:47,055
>> That's a good point,

1751
01:21:47,055 --> 01:21:51,430
cuz there is nothing built in to Microsoft
clustering that will replicate that data.

1752
01:21:51,430 --> 01:21:54,020
We have to use some kind
of third party utility.

1753
01:21:54,020 --> 01:21:57,385
>> The closest is the Microsoft SyncToy,
which is a piece of garbage.

1754
01:21:57,385 --> 01:21:58,326
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

1755
01:21:58,326 --> 01:21:59,903
>> You're gonna call it a toy,

1756
01:21:59,903 --> 01:22:01,100
you know it's not.

1757
01:22:01,100 --> 01:22:04,368
>> Yeah, that whole sync framework
that they have is not good.

1758
01:22:04,368 --> 01:22:08,960
So these vendors, EMC,
I've worked with theirs personally.

1759
01:22:08,960 --> 01:22:10,710
And theirs is top notch.

1760
01:22:10,710 --> 01:22:12,630
And it does use IFC.

1761
01:22:12,630 --> 01:22:16,120
So it is sending fiber channel
communications over a TCP/IP network.

1762
01:22:16,120 --> 01:22:21,540
But it allows you to replicate the entire
SAN, whatever you write to it is all being

1763
01:22:21,540 --> 01:22:28,040
replicated to another SAN somewhere else,
so the two SANs are effectively identical.

1764
01:22:28,040 --> 01:22:28,700
All right.

1765
01:22:28,700 --> 01:22:31,234
So then, I can build a cluster, and

1766
01:22:31,234 --> 01:22:36,993
even though these nodes are attached to
different SANs, they don't know that.

1767
01:22:36,993 --> 01:22:39,078
They think they're
attached to the same one,

1768
01:22:39,078 --> 01:22:42,780
because when these guys look at SAN number
one, they see a certain set of volumes.

1769
01:22:42,780 --> 01:22:47,420
When these guys look at SAN number two,
they see the same exact set of volumes.

1770
01:22:47,420 --> 01:22:49,730
They think they're
looking at the same SAN.

1771
01:22:51,170 --> 01:22:54,826
So when that's done,
we're pretty much golden, right?

1772
01:22:54,826 --> 01:22:57,995
After that, we really just set up the SAN
to run like we would normally expect,

1773
01:22:57,995 --> 01:22:58,930
and off we go.

1774
01:22:58,930 --> 01:22:59,910
All right.

1775
01:22:59,910 --> 01:23:03,010
Now, one thing we do need to be aware of,
though,

1776
01:23:03,010 --> 01:23:08,490
because the nodes don't realize that
they're looking at different SANs,

1777
01:23:08,490 --> 01:23:11,560
the nodes are all gonna
treat themselves equally.

1778
01:23:11,560 --> 01:23:14,470
So let's say this is a Hyper-V cluster.

1779
01:23:14,470 --> 01:23:19,410
And so I've got a VM here on Node 1,
and Node 1 fails.

1780
01:23:19,410 --> 01:23:26,410
That VM could then jump to Node 2,
could jump to Node 3 or Node 4.

1781
01:23:26,410 --> 01:23:28,250
We might not want that.

1782
01:23:28,250 --> 01:23:33,450
And so if we're gonna do
a multi-site cluster like this,

1783
01:23:33,450 --> 01:23:37,060
it is important that we put
some preferences in there.

1784
01:23:37,060 --> 01:23:43,060
And we say this VM prefers Node 1,
and then Node 2 comes second,

1785
01:23:43,060 --> 01:23:47,170
and after that, then you jump over
to the other facility over here.

1786
01:23:47,170 --> 01:23:50,000
Cuz I don't want everybody at my home
office having to reach across the wide

1787
01:23:50,000 --> 01:23:51,860
area network to get to that server.

1788
01:23:51,860 --> 01:23:52,610
Right?

1789
01:23:52,610 --> 01:23:58,165
Now, running plain old Hyper-V
right on top of Windows Server

1790
01:23:58,165 --> 01:24:02,740
2012, it doesn't give you a whole
heck of a lot for setting preference.

1791
01:24:02,740 --> 01:24:06,660
You can set a startup server, so you can
dictate which server you want it to start

1792
01:24:06,660 --> 01:24:09,750
up on, and then after that it doesn't
give you a whole lot of control.

1793
01:24:09,750 --> 01:24:13,500
But if you use
the System Center Virtual Machine Manager,

1794
01:24:13,500 --> 01:24:16,620
the SCVMM,
It does give you a lot of control.

1795
01:24:16,620 --> 01:24:18,830
And you can set preferences and
rank the servers and

1796
01:24:18,830 --> 01:24:21,790
stuff, and
kinda set where you'd prefer them to go

1797
01:24:21,790 --> 01:24:27,120
to make sure that they stay in the home
office unless the home office fails.

1798
01:24:27,120 --> 01:24:30,000
In which case then we jump
over to the other side.

1799
01:24:30,000 --> 01:24:34,190
So that's definitely something we need
to be aware of with a multi-site SAN.

1800
01:24:35,730 --> 01:24:38,230
There's also another thing to be aware of.

1801
01:24:38,230 --> 01:24:39,140
IP addresses.

1802
01:24:40,430 --> 01:24:45,145
Remember, that when we build a cluster,
every clustered resource has a virtual

1803
01:24:45,145 --> 01:24:49,390
IP address, and that virtual IP address
has to be in a particular subnet.

1804
01:24:49,390 --> 01:24:53,790
Now, subnets are typically
in one geographic location.

1805
01:24:53,790 --> 01:24:59,317
But if I have a virtual machine here,
with an IP of 192.168.0.100,

1806
01:24:59,317 --> 01:25:04,701
when it fails over to this side,
it's gonna be 192.168.0.100.

1807
01:25:04,701 --> 01:25:05,868
It's gonna be the same thing.

1808
01:25:05,868 --> 01:25:06,493
All right?

1809
01:25:06,493 --> 01:25:09,825
So we've got two choices
how we want to handle this.

1810
01:25:09,825 --> 01:25:13,455
One, we could set our servers up for
DHCP, right, that's gonna happen.

1811
01:25:13,455 --> 01:25:15,085
So that's not gonna happen.

1812
01:25:15,085 --> 01:25:15,920
>> Nope.

1813
01:25:15,920 --> 01:25:24,230
>> Or two, we make plans to have the same
subnet present in two different networks.

1814
01:25:24,230 --> 01:25:26,410
And there's a few ways to go about that.

1815
01:25:26,410 --> 01:25:31,466
If you're using a dynamic routing
protocol like OSPF or BGP,

1816
01:25:31,466 --> 01:25:37,701
you can use those routing protocols to
direct people to the traffic source.

1817
01:25:37,701 --> 01:25:42,680
So you can say 192.168.0.0/24 is here.

1818
01:25:42,680 --> 01:25:47,500
But then when a failure happens,
it'll redirect everybody over to here,

1819
01:25:47,500 --> 01:25:49,590
expecting that network to now
be in the other location.

1820
01:25:50,690 --> 01:25:54,680
The problem with that is,
what if it's not a full failure?

1821
01:25:54,680 --> 01:25:58,145
What if some of the machines for

1822
01:25:58,145 --> 01:26:02,740
192.168.1.0 are over here and others
are over here in this other building?

1823
01:26:02,740 --> 01:26:05,950
In that scenario, a dynamic routing
protocol's not going to help you.

1824
01:26:05,950 --> 01:26:10,340
What you're going to need is
some kind of a layer 2 tunnel

1825
01:26:10,340 --> 01:26:16,010
between these two locations, so
that the subnet can exist in both places.

1826
01:26:16,010 --> 01:26:17,940
A lot of times,
your storage area networks,

1827
01:26:17,940 --> 01:26:20,940
their replication software will
include that functionality.

1828
01:26:20,940 --> 01:26:22,760
But even if they don't,
you can build up your own.

1829
01:26:22,760 --> 01:26:24,440
You can do GRE tunnels,

1830
01:26:24,440 --> 01:26:29,870
generic routing encapsulation tunnels,
you can do layer 2 tunneling.

1831
01:26:29,870 --> 01:26:33,450
There's a couple of different
protocols that are available for that.

1832
01:26:33,450 --> 01:26:37,250
If you're running IPv6, though,
you can use IP mobility.

1833
01:26:37,250 --> 01:26:39,160
And then those machines will
be perfectly happy over there,

1834
01:26:39,160 --> 01:26:40,400
even though they're in the wrong subnet,

1835
01:26:40,400 --> 01:26:43,950
because IPv6 has the built-in
functionality to support that.

1836
01:26:43,950 --> 01:26:47,860
So, if you've moved to IPv6,
it's a much smaller problem.

1837
01:26:47,860 --> 01:26:52,090
But if you're in the IPv4 world, you've
got to build a tunnel of some sort so

1838
01:26:52,090 --> 01:26:57,710
that a broadcast over here on the 192.16.0
network gets forwarded to the other side,

1839
01:26:57,710 --> 01:26:59,380
and layer 3 routing is not gonna do that,
so

1840
01:26:59,380 --> 01:27:01,660
it's got to be a layer
2 tunnel of some sort.

1841
01:27:03,180 --> 01:27:05,410
So, those are some of the caveats.

And that process assumes you're on a LAN,

Well, if you're crossing a wide area

01:28:07,897 --> 01:28:11,650

1865

And it's not hard to manipulate.

1866

1867
01:28:16,800 --> 01:28:18,480

1868
01:28:18,480 --> 01:28:22,010
And basically you just tweak it to
increase the heartbeat level to

1869
01:28:22,010 --> 01:28:22,930
an acceptable level.

1870
01:28:22,930 --> 01:28:27,370
Now, understand the bigger that interval,
the longer the amount of

1871
01:28:27,370 --> 01:28:31,100
time between heartbeats is, the longer
it takes you to detect a failure.

1872
01:28:31,100 --> 01:28:33,170
>> Right.
>> So, when we did that failure earlier,

1873
01:28:33,170 --> 01:28:34,900
we lost, like what, two pings?

1874
01:28:34,900 --> 01:28:35,490
>> Yeah, one or two.

1875
01:28:35,490 --> 01:28:36,560
That was it.

1876
01:28:36,560 --> 01:28:39,220
>> So, for
every second that you increase it,

1877
01:28:39,220 --> 01:28:42,090
that's a bigger time
to detect the failure.

1878
01:28:42,090 --> 01:28:43,500
So you don't wanna go too big.

1879
01:28:43,500 --> 01:28:45,660
So you do have to do a little tuning and
tweaking.

1880
01:28:45,660 --> 01:28:46,840
Look at your network.

1881
01:28:46,840 --> 01:28:50,240
Figure out what you can get away with,
what the latency is on the line and

1882
01:28:50,240 --> 01:28:50,980
tweak it and adjust it.

1883
01:28:50,980 --> 01:28:56,115
There's no one size fits all on this one

All right, so

01:30:04,690 --> 01:30:08,600
we do have another consideration when

1912
01:30:08,600 --> 01:30:09,570
Let me go back to my diagram.

1913
01:30:10,840 --> 01:30:11,340
All right.

1914
01:30:12,560 --> 01:30:17,440
When we have a cluster with
an even amount of nodes,

1915
01:30:17,440 --> 01:30:21,450
we need a tie-breaker for
when there's a disconnect, right?

1916
01:30:22,880 --> 01:30:27,480
Normally, we can use a Storage based,
shared storage, witness right,

1917
01:30:27,480 --> 01:30:29,130
where we actually use our SAN.

1918
01:30:29,130 --> 01:30:30,010
Disk witness.

1919
01:30:30,010 --> 01:30:31,270
Yes, thanks Mike.

1920
01:30:31,270 --> 01:30:34,040
So, we normally use that
one as the witness.

1921
01:30:34,040 --> 01:30:39,000
When you have multiple SANs involved,
you cannot use a disk witness.

1922
01:30:39,000 --> 01:30:42,247
And the reason is,
if our WAN link goes down,

1923
01:30:42,247 --> 01:30:45,073
these guys can see their SAN just fine.

1924
01:30:45,073 --> 01:30:47,630
These guys can see their SAN just fine.

1925
01:30:47,630 --> 01:30:50,568
And that means they're both gonna
think that they're healthy and

1926
01:30:50,568 --> 01:30:53,180
that the other guy is down and
they're both gonna try and go active.

1927
01:30:53,180 --> 01:30:54,554
And that's not what you want.

1928
01:30:54,554 --> 01:31:01,330
So in a multi-location cluster,
you can't trust the SAN.

1929
01:31:01,330 --> 01:31:05,570
Even though that's where your
super sensitive data is,

1930
01:31:05,570 --> 01:31:07,900
you just can't trust it as a tie-breaker,
cuz there's two of them.

1931
01:31:07,900 --> 01:31:12,910
It would be like them getting two votes,
and now you're still at an even number,

1932
01:31:12,910 --> 01:31:14,480
so it's pointless.

1933
01:31:14,480 --> 01:31:17,380
So in a multi-site cluster like this, it's

1934
01:31:17,380 --> 01:31:21,480
really important that we use a file share
witness, which is what I stuck down here.

1935
01:31:21,480 --> 01:31:22,290
Okay?

1936
01:31:22,290 --> 01:31:23,959
Well here's the problem with
the file share witness.

1937
01:31:24,960 --> 01:31:27,860
If I stick it over here,
I've got my tie breaker.

1938
01:31:27,860 --> 01:31:28,573
Right?

1939
01:31:28,573 --> 01:31:29,900
>> For one side. [LAUGH] >> For one side.

1940
01:31:31,520 --> 01:31:36,220
And if the home office fails and SAN 2 is
all that's left, I got a tie right here

1941
01:31:36,220 --> 01:31:38,990
between these two guys and
I can't see the file share witness.

1942
01:31:38,990 --> 01:31:42,290
So I assume that I'm the problem,
not that they're the problem,

1943
01:31:42,290 --> 01:31:43,590
cuz I can't see the witness.

1944
01:31:43,590 --> 01:31:44,310
All right.

1945
01:31:44,310 --> 01:31:46,040
The same thing is true in
the opposite direction.

1946
01:31:46,040 --> 01:31:48,830
If we stick it over here, same problem.

1947
01:31:48,830 --> 01:31:52,070
The home office,
if the DR site completely goes out,

1948
01:31:52,070 --> 01:31:54,390
the home office loses
a connection to the witness.

1949
01:31:54,390 --> 01:31:58,030
>> And so it assumes that it's the problem
and the VMs don't come active.

1950
01:31:58,030 --> 01:31:59,750
Now You can go always go and
force them active.

1951
01:31:59,750 --> 01:32:01,890
It's not that big of a deal, right?

1952
01:32:01,890 --> 01:32:04,830
But if you're trying to get
high availability with as

1953
01:32:04,830 --> 01:32:08,460
little downtime as possible,
you don't want anything to be manual.

1954
01:32:08,460 --> 01:32:13,190
And so in a multi-site cluster,
it's important that not

1955
01:32:13,190 --> 01:32:18,550
only you use a file share witness, but
that it be located in a third site.

1956
01:32:18,550 --> 01:32:19,270
Okay?

1957
01:32:19,270 --> 01:32:23,140
It has to be in a third location,
somewhere else.

1958
01:32:23,140 --> 01:32:27,270
So if we bring into this
little model here, and

1959
01:32:27,270 --> 01:32:29,790
you know I didn't really leave
myself enough room for this.

1960
01:32:29,790 --> 01:32:32,140
>> It could be a little tiny
site down at the bottom.

1961
01:32:32,140 --> 01:32:35,880
>> Yeah, so maybe we contract with
somebody or we talk to our ISP,

1962
01:32:35,880 --> 01:32:38,590
and we say hey,
can we co-locate a server there?

1963
01:32:38,590 --> 01:32:40,850
Maybe we use a Windows Azure instance,
right?

1964
01:32:40,850 --> 01:32:43,279
>> Yeah.
Or Amazon EC.

1965
01:32:43,279 --> 01:32:46,466
Oh no that's right, EC2,
Elastic Compute Club.

1966
01:32:46,466 --> 01:32:49,752
So we bring up some instance out there.

1967
01:32:49,752 --> 01:32:51,865
>> Cuz this is just real low,
it's just file share, that's it.

1968
01:32:51,865 --> 01:32:52,948
>> Yeah, that's all we need.

1969
01:32:52,948 --> 01:32:57,844
>> And we bring up a third location
into our mix, and when we do that,

1970
01:32:57,844 --> 01:33:02,652
now we can have both sides connected
to this other location, and

1971
01:33:02,652 --> 01:33:04,660
they can communicate.

1972
01:33:04,660 --> 01:33:08,270
And then we just put our file
share witness out there.

1973
01:33:08,270 --> 01:33:13,220
The idea being,
if the home office were to fail,

1974
01:33:13,220 --> 01:33:17,270
the disaster recovery site could
still see the file share witness.

1975
01:33:17,270 --> 01:33:22,050
And it would know that it's not
the problem, it's okay to come active.

1976
01:33:22,050 --> 01:33:24,310
Or if the disaster recovery site failed,

1977
01:33:24,310 --> 01:33:27,660
the home office would still be able
to see the file share witness.

1978
01:33:27,660 --> 01:33:31,060
It would know that it's not the problem
and it would be okay to come active.

1979
01:33:31,060 --> 01:33:31,900
All right?

1980
01:33:31,900 --> 01:33:36,930
But if this WAN link failed, and the home
office just couldn't see the remotes.

1981
01:33:36,930 --> 01:33:38,190
I couldn't see the DR site.

1982
01:33:38,190 --> 01:33:40,820
It wouldn't be wouldn't be able to
see the file share witness either.

1983
01:33:40,820 --> 01:33:43,930
And the home office would know
that it was the problem and

1984
01:33:43,930 --> 01:33:45,640
it would know to take its servers down.

1985
01:33:45,640 --> 01:33:48,140
>> Right.
>> So that solves the problem but

1986
01:33:48,140 --> 01:33:51,060
it does require a third site.

1987
01:33:51,060 --> 01:33:55,120
We've got to move that file
share witness out there so

1988
01:33:55,120 --> 01:33:58,030
that it's honest,
that it can be that tie breaker.

1989
01:33:58,030 --> 01:33:59,750
So, for a small or

1990
01:33:59,750 --> 01:34:04,150
medium business, having that third site,
well that used be a real burden.

1991
01:34:04,150 --> 01:34:07,560
But thanks to Windows Azure,
Amazon EC2, Rackspace,

1992
01:34:07,560 --> 01:34:11,720
companies like that, it's so
easy to bring up that unit somewhere else.

1993
01:34:11,720 --> 01:34:13,670
It'll cost you, if you use Amazon right?

1994
01:34:13,670 --> 01:34:16,470
You do like one of their
really micro instances,

1995
01:34:16,470 --> 01:34:19,350
you can have a windows server up,
VPN into it.

1996
01:34:19,350 --> 01:34:23,400
It'll cost you, it's something like
$12.50 a month or something around that.

1997
01:34:23,400 --> 01:34:26,400
So it is not an expensive thing to do.

1998
01:34:26,400 --> 01:34:31,968
But the file share witness does
need to be in a third location.

1999
01:34:31,968 --> 01:34:36,610
>> What got me thinking about that
was the Global Update Manager.

2000
01:34:36,610 --> 01:34:40,450
The Global Update Manager is what
controls that file share witness.

2001
01:34:40,450 --> 01:34:43,380
And it turns out that
in Windows Server 2012,

2002
01:34:43,380 --> 01:34:47,710
there was a little quirk in the Global
Update Manager that was a problem.

2003
01:34:47,710 --> 01:34:48,500
Okay?

2004
01:34:48,500 --> 01:34:53,060
And the problem was,
machines had to write their little time

2005
01:34:53,060 --> 01:34:56,490
stamp file to the file share witness
that would say hey, I'm up, I'm happy.

2006
01:34:57,690 --> 01:35:02,820
And if they ever stopped writing to that
file, then we assumed they were down.

2007
01:35:02,820 --> 01:35:03,510
Okay?

2008
01:35:03,510 --> 01:35:07,610
Well, when we assume someone is down,
we need to take care of it.

2009
01:35:07,610 --> 01:35:12,130
And so any of the nodes that
are still up need to check in.

2010
01:35:12,130 --> 01:35:13,250
They all vote, right?

2011
01:35:13,250 --> 01:35:17,300
We get our quorum, and
when they decide that there is a failure,

2012
01:35:17,300 --> 01:35:21,450
each of the nodes has to
acknowledge the failure, okay?

2013
01:35:21,450 --> 01:35:26,390
And only when all of the remaining nodes,
so every node that is still online,

2014
01:35:26,390 --> 01:35:28,855
you don't care about the offline guys,
but the nodes that are online,

2015
01:35:28,855 --> 01:35:33,535
only once all of them had said yes,
let's fail over, would it fail over.

2016
01:35:33,535 --> 01:35:37,325
Well, there were a few little bugs that
could every now and then lead to one or

2017
01:35:37,325 --> 01:35:45,057
two nodes either not voting ever or just
being delayed, and taking a while to vote.

2018
01:35:45,057 --> 01:35:47,458
And it would slow the fail over down.

2019
01:35:47,458 --> 01:35:51,793
So in Windows 2012 R2,
they changed that behavior and

2020
01:35:51,793 --> 01:35:56,050
now you don't have to wait for
all of the nodes to check in.

2021
01:35:56,050 --> 01:35:59,625
You just have to wait for
a majority of the nodes to check-in, and

2022
01:35:59,625 --> 01:36:01,380
then the failover will happen.

2023
01:36:01,380 --> 01:36:04,580
That speeds up the failover, and
it solves that little quirk.

2024
01:36:04,580 --> 01:36:08,460
Now because that's new functionality,
you can expect it to be on the exam.

2025
01:36:08,460 --> 01:36:09,540
This is something they can turn on.

2026
01:36:10,640 --> 01:36:17,320
So I pulled up the article on where they
published that change, and it is here.

2027
01:36:17,320 --> 01:36:22,950
And you'll see where they're basically
talking about the Global Update Manager,

2028
01:36:22,950 --> 01:36:25,560
here we go, and
how it just changed the mode.

2029
01:36:25,560 --> 01:36:27,260
And if you're happy with
the new functionality,

2030
01:36:27,260 --> 01:36:29,905
great, you should leave it be,
you don't do anything.

2031
01:36:29,905 --> 01:36:35,295
But if for some reason you need to
force it back to the 2012 way, you can.

2032
01:36:35,295 --> 01:36:40,135
There's a PowerShell command you can run
which is the Get-Cluster command, and

2033
01:36:40,135 --> 01:36:42,270
you can pull the database read write mode.

2034
01:36:42,270 --> 01:36:43,760
And that's the Global Update Manager mode.

2035
01:36:43,760 --> 01:36:46,590
And you'll see there's three options.

2036
01:36:46,590 --> 01:36:51,440
Zero, which is everybody has to check-in,
and that's the old way.

2037
01:36:51,440 --> 01:36:56,310
There's one, just a majority has to
check-in, and that's the new way.

2038
01:36:56,310 --> 01:37:00,560
And then there's the majority write and
local read, and that means in order for

2039
01:37:00,560 --> 01:37:03,430
somebody to be able to
bring the system up,

2040
01:37:03,430 --> 01:37:07,710
they don't have to necessarily be
able write to the File Share Witness.

2041
01:37:07,710 --> 01:37:10,380
They just need to be able to read to
see that status and then go ahead and

2042
01:37:10,380 --> 01:37:11,430
make it happen.

2043
01:37:11,430 --> 01:37:16,560
So the default is one and that's normally
what we want, and that's basically it.

2044
01:37:16,560 --> 01:37:20,080
But you can change it back
to the old one if you want.

2045
01:37:20,080 --> 01:37:24,420
Instead of Get-Cluster, you would do
a Set-Cluster and modify that value.

2046
01:37:24,420 --> 01:37:27,550
Now they go on to say,
you don't wanna mess with this.

2047
01:37:27,550 --> 01:37:31,450
If you read through here, somewhere
in here, they say, oh, right here.

2048
01:37:31,450 --> 01:37:34,120
Do not use either majority modes one or
two for

2049
01:37:34,120 --> 01:37:39,120
anywhere where you need strong
consistency guarantees.

2050
01:37:39,120 --> 01:37:41,770
The old way required unanimity, right?

2051
01:37:41,770 --> 01:37:43,010
>> They all had to be in sync, yeah.

2052
01:37:43,010 --> 01:37:44,040
>> Everybody, and so

2053
01:37:44,040 --> 01:37:47,870
if you relied upon that, then you wanna
go back to the old way, go back to zero.

2054
01:37:48,940 --> 01:37:53,405
But for most us, we're more concerned
about rapidity, getting back online as

2055
01:37:53,405 --> 01:37:57,595
fast as possible and so the new default
mode of one is what we're going to want.

2056
01:37:58,935 --> 01:38:01,955
So that is a little change,
just something to be aware of and

2057
01:38:01,955 --> 01:38:05,210
again, not something most of
us are gonna mess with it.

2058
01:38:05,210 --> 01:38:07,200
That's a hard one to remember.

2059
01:38:07,200 --> 01:38:09,120
It's a hidden thing that kind
of runs in the background.

2060
01:38:09,120 --> 01:38:10,820
Most of us never even think about it.

2061
01:38:10,820 --> 01:38:13,410
I'll post a link to that article
with the show notes also, just so

2062
01:38:13,410 --> 01:38:18,980
you can take a look at it and
make sure that you understand that.

2063

Mike, let's see what else

2070
01:38:28,850 --> 01:38:33,970
>> But you can't understate how
important disaster recovery is.

2071
01:38:33,970 --> 01:38:37,210
I mean, you don't think about it
when your network is running fine.

2072
01:38:37,210 --> 01:38:39,920
When the network's running fine,
disaster recovery is not a big deal.

2073
01:38:39,920 --> 01:38:44,250
But when you're in a failure,
every step you take to prepare for

2074

2075

2078

during the disaster itself.

2079
01:38:55,420 --> 01:38:57,200
That's not when you wanna decide.

2080

What order should I bring
these machines back up in?

2081
01:38:59,790 --> 01:39:00,580
And things like that.

2082
01:39:00,580 --> 01:39:04,940
That all needs to be planned out,
tested, re-evaluated every so often.

2083

So a very important part of our process.

Personally, I love the forums,

topics.title: Implement business continuity and disaster recovery

episodes.description: In this episode Nate and Mike take a look at advanced configuration of network services. They demonstrate creating DHCP superscopes and multicast scopes as well as failover and Name Protection. They discuss DNS GlobalNames zones and demonstrate configuring Domain Name System Security Extensions (DNSSEC). They wrap up with deploying IP Address Management (IPAM).

Yeah so, you know, superscopes,

again another thing we've talked about in

if we do like a class C scope, do you

So you start out with a company and

And you start out, you got a

00:02:56,020 --> 00:02:59,195

55
00:02:59,195 --> 00:03:03,635

00:03:03,635 --> 00:03:05,978

[LAUGH]

00:03:16,940 --> 00:03:17,890

00:03:44,820 --> 00:03:49,350

episodes.description: In this episode Mike and Don take a look at configuring an Active Directory forest and domain. They explain how to modify existing domains and forests in the event of upgrades or expansions. They also describe using universal principle names (UPN) suffixes. episodes.description: In this episode Mike and Don wrap up configuring Active Directory with discussion and demonstration of configuring trusts and sites. They discuss the differences of external, forest, shortcut and realm trusts as well as trust authentication. They give scenarios on creating sites and managing site coverage as well as the registration of SRV records and domain controller movement between sites.

episodes.description: In this episode Mike and Don break down the Certificate Services role and its use inside an enterprise environment. They begin by installing the role, configuring certificate revocation lists (CRLs) and implementing a backup and recovery solution. They also demonstrate certificate deployment, certificate renewal and managing key archival and recovery.

00:03:06,510 --> 00:03:10,030

00:03:10,030 --> 00:03:13,510

that's the person who's

00:05:33,310 --> 00:05:36,250

00:06:31,940 --> 00:06:36,060

00:06:36,060 --> 00:06:38,070

00:06:38,070 --> 00:06:41,440
That does not matter,
you can do it on Standard or Datacenter.

140
00:06:41,440 --> 00:06:46,100
The first one we create is a special CA,

141
00:06:46,100 --> 00:06:50,030

142
00:06:50,030 --> 00:06:53,520
And then underneath that,
we'll create subordinate CAs.

143
00:06:53,520 --> 00:06:57,660
When we try to decide how we are going to
set up our hierarchy, we can do it for

144
00:06:57,660 --> 00:06:58,700

145
00:06:58,700 --> 00:07:01,380
Our root CA is typically very protective.

146
00:07:01,380 --> 00:07:05,840
The one thing we want to keep in mind,
if the root CA ever becomes compromised,

147
00:07:05,840 --> 00:07:09,380
then everything underneath that
is considered compromised,

148
00:07:09,380 --> 00:07:12,200
I can't trust any of the certificates
that he's ever issued.

149
00:07:12,200 --> 00:07:16,130
So if he becomes compromised,
my whole PKI has to be redone.

150
00:07:16,130 --> 00:07:20,170
So what normally happens is we're gonna
set up that first certificate authority,

151
00:07:20,170 --> 00:07:23,280
that root CA, and
we're gonna take him offline.

152
00:07:23,280 --> 00:07:26,740
He's gonna issue certificates
to subordinate CAs, and

153
00:07:26,740 --> 00:07:31,030
then the subordinate CAs are the ones that
actually issue the certificates to users,

154
00:07:31,030 --> 00:07:32,780
to the computers, and things like that.

155
00:07:32,780 --> 00:07:34,840
The root is taken offline and

156
00:07:34,840 --> 00:07:37,970
only brought online to maybe
do some updates now and again.

157
00:07:37,970 --> 00:07:39,900
He's usually not part of the domain.

158
00:07:39,900 --> 00:07:43,070
He's not tied into active
